abstract.p: Ian Alterman letter comments on May 16 article on left-handedness

block.p: Re ''On Left-Handedness, Its Causes and Costs'' (May 16): The geneticist Amar Klar seems to be on the right track when he says, ''I'm not interested in handedness per se, I'm interested in how the brain works.''

It is well documented that the left side of the brain controls the right side of the body (and certain cognitive functions, primarily intellectual and analytical), and that the right side of the brain controls the left side of the body (and other cognitive functions, primarily creative). Thus, the idea of a genetic marker for predisposed right- or left-handedness would seem to be valid only if it affected the formation of the brain itself.

Re ''On Left-Handedness, Its Causes and Costs'' (May 16): The geneticist Amar Klar seems to be on the right track when he says, ''I'm not interested in handedness per se, I'm interested in how the brain works.''

It is well documented that the left side of the brain controls the right side of the body (and certain cognitive functions, primarily intellectual and analytical), and that the right side of the brain controls the left side of the body (and other cognitive functions, primarily creative). Thus, the idea of a genetic marker for predisposed right- or left-handedness would seem to be valid only if it affected the formation of the brain itself.

As a southpaw, I have followed the scientific and sociopsychological debates about left-handedness for many years. But I have always remained secure in the knowledge that if the right and left sides of the brain control the opposite sides of the body, then it is only left-handed people who are in their right minds.
